title: 106_hr583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System and Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The Act "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the definition of an Assistant United States Attorney in the Civil Service Retirement System and Federal Employees' Retirement System. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the first pay period after a 90-day period from the date of enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. For purposes of this section, an incumbent is an individual first appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act. The Department of Justice must provide notice to these individuals regarding their election rights under this Act within 6 months of its effective date. Incumbents have the option to elect to be treated in accordance with the amendments made by this Act or to be treated as if the Act had never been enacted. Failure to make a timely election will result in consequences. Failure to timely elect under this subsection will be treated as if the election was made on the last allowable day. The election must be made before the 90th day after receiving notice or the incumbent separates from service. No changes in retirement coverage will occur until an election is made. Retroactive effect applies to those who elect the option under subsection (c)(1)(A). The individual, if electing the option under subsection (c)(1)(A), will have all service as an Assistant United States Attorney treated according to the amended provisions of chapter 83 or 84 of title 5, United States Code. Makeup contributions are required from the Department of Justice in addition to other payments under subchapter III of chapter 83 or chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code. The Department of Justice must remit the specified amount to the Office of Personnel Management, which will then deposit it into the Treasury of the United States for the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. This amount includes additional individual and Government contributions for Assistant United States Attorneys before their election under subsection (c). The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for the Act, including determining interest on contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined in the section. No individual liability is created for contribution shortfalls.
